bestBHT.bht: These false teachers have forsaken the right way and are following in the footsteps of Balaam, who loved the wages of unrighteousness. They are like wells without water and mists driven by a whirlwind, destined for darkness. Balaam, known as the enticer of Israel to lust and the son of carnality, coveted the rewards of his own wrongdoing and advised Israel to engage in fleshly desires and idolatry. Let us be cautious of those who imitate Balaam, promoting wickedness and seeking unrighteous rewards.

Henry Alford: Which have forsaken the right way and are gone astray, following out the way of Balaam, who loved the wages of unrighteousness, but had a rebuke for his own iniquity."
A dumb beast of burden speaking in man's voice hindered the madness of the prophet."
These are wells without water and mists driven along by a whirlwind, for whom the blackness of darkness is reserved.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: This word was adopted, perhaps, because the kindred word Basar means flesh; and Balaam is justly termed son of carnality, as covetous, and the enticer of Israel to lust.

Loved the wages of unrighteousness—and therefore wished (in order to gain them from Balak) to curse Israel whom God had blessed, and at last gave the hellish counsel that the only way to bring God's curse on Israel was to entice them to fleshly lust and idolatry, which often go together.
Balaam is justly termed son of carnality, as covetous, and the enticer of Israel to lust.
Albert Barnes: Religion is often represented as a straight path, and to do wrong is to go out of that path in a crooked way.

Possibly, however, he might have designed to refer to a more general resemblance, for in fact they imitated him in the following things: (1) In being professed religious teachers, or the servants of God; (2) In their covetousness; (3) In inducing others to sin, referring to the same kind of sins in both cases.
Balaam was undoubtedly a wicked man, and was constrained by a power from on high to utter sentiments which God meant should be uttered, but which Balaam would never have expressed of his own accord.
Marvin Vincent: Right [ευθειαν] . Lit., straight, which is the radical meaning of right.
Following [εξακολουθησαντες] . See on ch. 2 Peter 1:16; 2 Peter 2:2. Compare Jude 1:11.
The way. Note the frequent occurrence of the word way in the story of Balaam (Numbers 22:0), and Peter's use of the same phrase, as here, the right ways of the Lord, in Acts 13:10.
John Calvin: They spread by their teaching the deadly poison of impiety, in order that they might destroy the simple.
Balaam was reproved by an ass, and thus his madness was condemned.
The mouth of the ass was opened, that he who had been unwilling to submit to God's authority might have that as his teacher.
Philip Schaff: forsaking the straight way they went astray, having followed the way of Balaam the son of Bosor, who loved the wages of unrighteousness.
The strong verb for a following which amounts to close pursuit or imitation is used here again.
The fact that in Revelation 2:14-15 the Nicolaitans are mentioned in connection with Balaam, leads some to the conclusion that Peter also had that party in his view here.
Archibald T. Robertson: The way of Balaam, 'who loved the hire of wrong-doing'.
John Gill: The right way of the Lord, the way of truth, the Gospel of truth; or Christ, who is the way, the truth, and the life; the true way to eternal life.
The way of Balaam [the son] of Bosor; which Jude calls his error, and is the path of covetousness, uncleanness, and idolatry.
He loved the wages of unrighteousness: which were the rewards of divination, which were brought him for his divining or soothsaying, and may well be called unrighteous wages.
John Wesley: The way of Balaam the son of Bosor — So the Chaldeans pronounced what the Jews termed Beor; namely, the way of covetousness.
Who loved — Earnestly desired, though he did not dare to take, the reward of unrighteousness - The money which Balak would have given him for cursing Israel.

bhtAttempts.bht: These false teachers have forsaken the right way and are following in the footsteps of Balaam, who loved the wages of unrighteousness. They are like empty wells and fleeting mists, bringing darkness upon themselves. Balaam, known as the son of carnality and the enticer of Israel to lust, desired the rewards of wrongdoing and counseled Israel to indulge in fleshly desires and idolatry. They have strayed from the straight path of righteousness and imitated Balaam's ways, just as he had imitated the way of the Lord. Let us be aware of those who, like Balaam, promote wickedness and seek the unrighteous rewards of their deeds.
